The members of the Medical Research Council and their sub-committees and the members of the Medico-Social Research Board have invested a great deal of their time freely in this important work. I look forward to greater co-operation with both bodies in the years ahead.
As he will be retiring within the next 12 months, I wish to record particular thanks to Dr. Geoffrey Dean of the Medico-Social Research Board for his outstanding work as Director in recent years.

Despite the rapid growth and development of health services over the past 20 years or so the prevalence of conditions requiring medical attention is not diminishing — in fact, the available evidence seems to suggest the contrary.

Yet many of the illnesses and diseases which now plague our society are in large measure preventable. Some conditions such as heart disease, cancer, alcoholism and accidents are major contributors to illness and premature death and place a severe burden on the health services and the Exchequer. The adverse effects of these conditions can in many cases be avoided by actions taken outside the realm of health services.

Within the ferment about our present state and future prospects there is one area I believe which presents itself as a focus of agreement between the critics and defenders of the health services in this country — promotion of positive health.

There are two aspects to positive health which I feel need promoting. First of all, there is the person's own behaviour. If we are fortunate enough to be born free of any major illness or disability and if we wish to maintain our good health we must not depart radically from the pattern of personal behaviour under which man has evolved, for example, by smoking, over-eating, over-drinking or sedentary living. All these things apply to politicians. Health is a limited resource and needs to be husbanded and protected by pursuing a style of life which gives health every chance.

The second and most difficult factor to control is the external or environmental conditions. Recent research would indicate that the person's health is greatly influenced by conditions outside his own control. Factors of environmental pollution, urbanisation, economic recession, unemployment, and other stresses and insecurities have as much to do with ill-health as do individual lifestyles.

These contradictions in our society must be dealt with before a worthwhile change in the health status of Irish people can take place. In promoting the concept of positive health, therefore, we will be seeking not only the co-operation of the individual but also of the various organisations and bodies which influence the environment in which that person lives. The State is obviously a major influence in this area but it is not the only one. Industry, professional organisations, trade unions, sporting organisations, community based groups, pressure groups, multi-national companies producing and distributing consumable and other goods all have a part to play.

If the concept of health promotion is successful it should, for example, contribute to the lengthening of average life expectancy and improve the quality of life, limit early disability and enable people to use both their working and their leisure time productively in the national interest.

The concept of promoting health and of being conscious of the health implications of all our political, economic and social initiatives is a very idealistic one and will probably be slow to propagate. But it is an area which we must explore, and I hope to deal with it in greater detail in the coming Green Paper on the health services.

I wish to thank the 60,000 people who work in the health services. They are currently under enormous pressure but I have no doubt they will meet the challenges I will pose to them this year. In particular I want to thank the Secretary, Assistant Secretaries, Principal Officers and all the other grades with which I am in daily contact in the Department of Health. The portfolios of Health and Social Welfare constitute an impossible task in terms of governmental work. However, the task would be wholly impossible were it not for the outstanding co-operation, wisdom, advice and guidance which I have received from the executive and professional staff of the Department of Health in the past 12 months, advice which is available to all Members of the Houses of the Oireachtas, for which we are grateful and which is rarely acknowledged in Estimate debates.
I regret I have taken such a lengthy time moving this Estimate and it gives me great pleasure to recommend it to the House.

Speaker.P: We have listened to a marathon speech by the Minister this morning. Those who thought that there might be something in the speech ensuring that adequate health services would be provided will be disappointed. There was nothing in the statement to bring any relief. The Minister admitted several times that there would be curtailment of services this year. Our concern is to ensure that an adequate health service will be provided. In view of the massive cutbacks for which the Minister is responsible this is not possible in 1984.

Some of the cutbacks are as follows: Mid-Western Health Board, £3.2 million; North-Eastern Health Board, £1.9 million; South-Eastern Health Board, £3.5 million; and Southern Health Board, £4.2 million. In previous years efforts have been made by the health boards to cut out any wastage. They looked at all areas of services including supply, energy, transport and housekeeping, and measures were taken to trim operations without causing any hardship. It is no longer possible to cut back on the amount of finance being made available while expecting an adequate level of service to be provided.

It is interesting that the Minister complimented those involved in administration on the manner in which they have carried out their duties. I would agree entirely. This applies to officials in the Department and at health board level. Only a few weeks ago during an RTE programme the Minister asked why the South-Eastern Health Board could not save £1 million this year when they could do so last year. That is an indication that the Minister is divorced from the reality of what is happening.

MainHeading.P: The Mid-Western Health Board held a meeting and found that the Minister's allocation would fall £0.8 million short of the amount needed to administer services in an appropriate way during 1984. They wrote to the Minister to that effect, pointing out that they needed an extra allocation. In a letter dated 24 January the Minister stated that there were no funds at his disposal which would enable him to increase the non-capital allocation for any health agency in the current year. The CEO of the board in a letter to members on 17 February stated that a reduction of this magnitude could not be met without an impact of the service, and a reduction in the standard of patient care was inevitable. That is the result of this Government's health policy. We would not accept that it is necessary to have a reduction in the standard of patient care. It is essential to maintain an adequate level of service.

The Mid-Western Health Board decided to cut £80,000 from the ad hoc dental scheme. The Minister said this morning that he had set up a committee to carry out a general review of the dental service. He said that one of the aims of the review would be to identify and in so far as possible eliminate shortcomings in the existing services. We find that the Mid-Western Health Board have to reduce their ad hoc service by £80,000, while the Southern Health Board do not have an ad hoc dental service. The Minister should state publicly that he is not able to provide the statutory dental service which he is obliged to provide and that people should go elsewhere if they have dental cares rather than wait for the public dental service. It might be too late for dental fillings by the time their turn would come. This is a result of the cut-backs and the lack of commitment by the Government to community health care.

The Mid-Western Health Board also propose to cut back on drugs, medicines, surgical and medical appliances, dressings and bandages in the hospitals. They also propose to charge patients travelling to and from work at Shannon and they hope to raise £25,000. It will not be possible to give the increased allowances to those in long-term care. These cutbacks are in addition to those which have already been announced, such as a reduction in the amount of locum cover and temporary substitutes during periods of annual and sick leave, elimination of overtime for maintenance staff, reduction of overtime payments to junior hospital doctors, a limitation on the call-out payments to radiographers and laboratory technicians, reduction of premium payments to be achieved by reducing staffing of hospitals at weekends when medical procedures are normally scaled down, payments not to be made to student nurses for a preliminary training period of six weeks. These are the measures being taken by the Mid-Western Health Board, and other health boards have introduced similar cutbacks.

It seems that the Minister is more concerned with statistics than with the delivery of a service. We heard about reforms, costs per patient in hospital and all the different committees. The Minister said:
For example, we are looking at the possibility of setting down criteria for admission of in-patients to hospitals.

There is only one way in which the criteria for admitting a patient to hospital can be decided, and that is on the clinical judgment of the doctor. I do not know of any other way. Unless we adhere rigidly to that method, the lives of patients will be put at risk. If we are to be presented with criteria by the Minister or the Department for admissions to hospital, the lives of patients will be at risk.

Other important reductions which are relevant to most of the health boards are in the budget. There is minimal provision for additional and replacement medical equipment. The provision for furniture, crockery and hardware has been reduced very substantially and only breakages can be replaced. I am quoting from the letter from the CEO of the Western Health Board. The provision for bedding and clothing has been similarly reduced, and maintenance of hospitals and hospital equipment has been curtailed to an absolute minimum. These are indications of the types of cutbacks being implemented as a result of the Government's budgetary policy and their health policy for this year.

In a letter to the health boards on 15 December the Minister said that the public service embargo relating to filling only one in three vacancies would apply to the health service. Wisdom descended upon him and on 6 February he wrote to the health boards — probably having realised that it was totally unrealistic to expect to fill one in three surgical vacancies or one in three nursing vacancies — and told them it would not apply in 1984 but that they will have to find the money themselves.

The hospital services will certainly suffer as a result of these financial difficulties. The Minister has caused a great deal of confusion in some hospitals. When he closed the maternity unit in Bantry he promised that an antenatal facility would be available staffed by the hospitals in Cork. My understanding is that the consultants in Cork believe that is not feasible, that it is not practical, and that a safe service could not be provided at a distance of 60 miles. There is difficulty in providing the service the Minister promised.

In my own constituency the Minister wrote to the health board and told them they would have to close the hospital and sell it before he would sign the contract for the building of the new hospital in Cavan. He told them they would have to close the Monaghan hospital and dispose of it. Again he changed his mind and decided that we could maintain a medical and surgical service but not a maternity service. Obviously the Minister has no conception of the terrain in Cavan-Monaghan. The winters are long, with frost and a fair share of snow. We know 96 per cent of deliveries are normal, but we cannot expect a mother to put her own life and her baby's life at risk if she has to travel 40, 50 or 60 miles to a hospital in Cavan.

That is the type of policy we have had from this Government over the past year. The figures for admissions to hospital must be a matter of concern to people who need hospitalisation. In 1960, 250,000 people were admitted to hospital, and 389,500 were admitted in 1971. The figure for 1982 was 571,000. It has more than doubled in the past 20 years. That must be a matter of concern. There is no indication from the Minister that he has any radical solution to that problem. If we are to cut down the rate of admissions we must provide adequate out-patient services. The whole thrust of the Government's philosophy and policy is against any improvement in any of the services.

The Department and the Minister must realise that if we are to have the type of out-patient services which will ensure that there will be a reduction in the number of admissions to hospital they must be financed. That can only be done by building up the out-patient services. It would be a very good investment if the Minister were to spend money on developing out-patient services but he must do that in advance of closing down hospitals or people will suffer.

The community care services will suffer this year as a result of the cutbacks. Last year the Minister told us he expected that the report of the working party on the general medical services would be available by September 1983. In June last year he expected to have it in three months. On 1 March we still have not got it. That is the story in the Minister's speech this morning. Everything we were promised last year is still coming and nothing has arrived as yet.

The general medical services give good value for money. For approximately £100 million they cover one-third of the population and provide medical services for them for 24 hours a day and seven days a week. That is a good service. Last year the Minister withdrew the general medical services from the elderly. All old age pensioners were entitled to medical cards when the Minister took office but he withdrew these services from them this time last year. Obviously he realised that was a mistake, and it was announced in the budget this year that the guidelines were to be improved for eligibility for those over 66 years of age.

It was announced this morning that that will not take effect until 1 July. Why will it not take effect until 1 July? I believe that the Government recognised that it was necessary to have a higher level of income in the guidelines for pensioners. As the Minister said, while they make up 10 per cent of the population they take up 40 per cent of the places in hospital. They are more prone to illness. If they needed a higher level of income in the guidelines for the general medical services they needed it from the day the Government decided that, and it should have applied from the date of the budget and not 1 July. This makes one wonder about Government thinking on this issue. If they believed it was not necessary to improve the guidelines, why introduce this measure? If it was necessary to introduce guidelines to ensure elderly people would be able to provide for their illness, it should have been introduced from the date of the budget.

This morning we heard a long statement from the Minister about the withdrawal of medical cards from students. We do not believe this move will save the £2.5 million he expects, because from his figures the average number of visits per student per year is two and that will not yield £2.5 million. It is interesting to note that over the last three months, since the regulations were published, the Minister was not prepared to make any statement of interpretation of the new regulations. Seven students were allowed go to prison before he communicated with them and put his new interpretation on the regulations. The regulations clearly state that the services under the relevant sections of the Health Act shall not extend to persons between the ages of 16 and 25 years who are dependants of persons who do not have full eligibility for the services. Regulation No. 4 states that these regulations shall come into operation on 1 January 1984. This morning the Minister told us he had agreed with the students that the regulations would not come into operation until such time as they had an opportunity to apply for medical cards. Otherwise, there was no change from what he stated on 16 December when he announced the regulations. Had the Minister come into this House or met the students and told them three months ago that their medical cards were not being withdrawn on 1 January, perhaps he could have avoided the situation where the students had to go to prison.

I would like the Minister to look at the use of the general medical services cards for a variety of other purposes. This card entitles the holder not to be responsible for the youth employment levy, health contributions and the special 1 per cent levy. It entitles the holder's family to a free school bus service. Is it legitimate to use the medical card for such purposes, because obviously it is causing very serious social injustice? This morning he gave an example of a person with a wife and two children with a gross weekly income of £117 paying £20 rent and £10 travelling expenses. He is entitled to a medical card, but if he had £118 gross he would not be entitled to a medical card, and in the present situation would not receive a medical card, even under a hardship clause unless there was chronic illness in the house. The fact that he had other financial commitments would not influence the health board because of the cutbacks. Let us take two couples each with two children living side by side in two semi-detached houses. One of them has £117 gross and pays £30 between rent and travelling expenses. In addition to free medical services, he will receive free dental and ophthalmic services for himself, his wife and family. His school-going children will be entitled to travel free on the school bus and he will be absolved from the 3 per cent levies. His neighbour with £119 gross will pay the 3 per cent levies and £150 a year for the school bus. There is no social justice in that.

Instead of reviewing the criteria for admitting somebody to hospital, the Minister should review the administration and guidelines of the general medical services. We could also ask if it is right that gross income should be considered. Why not net income? The unemployed are entitled to all the services we provide for them, but they get a net income while their next door neighbour who is working is not entitled to these services although his net income may be lower.

This morning the Minister told us the number of consultations in the general medical services had increased to five million. I would like to know if the number of visits per patient has increased over the last ten years. The Minister also told us about the three categories of eligibility — full eligibility, limited eligibility and the upper income group. He defined full eligibility, saying that persons in that category were entitled to a full range of health services without charge and they were issued with medical cards for presentation when services are needed. That used to be correct, but it is not correct any longer, because they are not entitled to free dental services or drugs they may need. For example, general medical services cardholders who need white stomach mixtures are not entitled to them without charge because they have been withdrawn. One was on the list when the Minister took office but he saw to it that it was removed later. I should like to ask the Minister to tell the House the number of students who will retain medical cards as a result of the discussions he had with them. Will that number be increased? The Minister announced a figure of 40,000 but this morning we were told that it is 35,000. It appears that the figure has been reduced and I should like to know if the change in the number is as a result of recent discussions with students.

On the question of drugs, the Coalition partners promised that if elected to Government they would review the items removed from the GMS list. That was to be undertaken without delay and the Coalition undertook to restore items considered to be medically necessary. That undertaking was contained in their Programme for Government which stated that there would be a review of the recent removal of the over-the-counter items from the medical card scheme and refund scheme with a view to restoring to GMS patients without delay those items which are medically necessary. Perhaps it would have been better for the patients if the Government had not reviewed that list because the result of their review is that they increased the number of items removed by 233 to the end of June last. Instead of 900 items being removed, the Government removed more than 1,100 items, including such essential medicines as white stomach mixtures and certain cough bottles. Some of those were still on the list after the first list of drugs removed from the GMS list was announced.

I should now like to deal with the raising of the threshold for the drug refund scheme to £28 per month, £7 per week. That decision will cause a lot of hardship for many people. I have quoted the example of neighbours, one earning £117 per week and the other earning £119 or £120 per week. If the latter need drugs they will have to pay £7 per week. If the drugs are expensive they will have to wait up to three months for a refund of the amount in excess of £28 per month. In a month they may have to pay out £60 or £70 but they will have to wait three months for the refund. I accept that health boards have the power to grant medical cards in cases of hardship but in times of recession and financial stringency with the Minister curtailing services the boards are more strict in the administration of services in an effort to save money. They are concerned not to exceed the allocation given by the Department. They have been told by the Minister that he does not have any more funds at his disposal to give to them. The decision to increase the threshold affects the poorer sections of our community. Families with less than £6,000 per year are being asked to pay £20 rent for a house, £10 per week for travelling expenses to work, a 3 per cent levy on income, a fee for school buses if the children must avail of that service and £7 per week for drugs. The Minister should review the long-term illness scheme. Under that scheme those suffering from such chronic illnesses as bronchial asthma or cystic fibrosis, or those who are on continuous medication, are entitled to free drugs. The Minister should review that scheme rather than tinkering with the existing system or increasing the threshold under the drugs refund scheme.

Under the community care scheme there have been cutbacks in the transport facilities available and they hit the poorer sections of the community. I am aware of an elderly man who has severe arthritis and had to forego an appointment with the orthopaedic surgeon because he did not have transport. That transport was available to him before the cutbacks. Is the Minister satisfied with the arrangements for travel that exist? Are people being sent on public transport who are not suited for it? Are young people being asked to use public transport to get to Dublin city and told to locate the hospital themselves? In those cases health boards provided transport previously. I am not against a curtailment of the old transport arrangements because I accept that some people who were in a position to provide their own transport availed of the health board service. There is nothing wrong with eliminating that but I am concerned that the Minister appears to have gone too far and left people who need proper medical attention without the means of transport to see specialists and others.

In the budget there was an extension of the free travel scheme for certain categories of handicapped persons travelling to and from rehabilitation centres. Those people now enjoy free travel at any time of the day. The Minister should ensure that that concession is extended to all handicapped people irrespective of whether they are travelling to rehabilitation centres or not. I am concerned about a student who is blind and is attending a university in the city. That student is anxious to return home each weekend but the only bus available goes between 4 p.m. and 6 p.m. on a Friday and he is not allowed use his free travel facility at that time. Will the Minister see if he can do something for that person?

The Irish Wheelchair Association have been seeking an improvement in their residential care facilities for those who are handicapped. Will the Minister use his influence with the Minister for the Environment to ensure that local authorities provide suitable housing for handicapped persons? The policy of some local authorities is most unacceptable. They will not allocate single storey houses to handicapped people. They build them for the elderly but will not give them to the handicapped. This matter must be raised at Government level by the Ministers for Health and the Environment to ensure that in this day and age a handicapped person who wants to live in a community is given proper and adequate housing.

Concern was also expressed by that association about younger handicapped persons who are maintained in residential care institutions of health boards. They are subject to hospital discipline, and I must agree with them that young people should be given as much freedom as possible wherever their residential care happens to be. If they cannot live in the community then they should be allowed the maximum freedom possible commensurate with the proper running of the hospital.

The Minister stated that the collection of health contributions should be transfered from the health boards to the Revenue Commissioners. That is desirable. It should never have been a function of the health boards to act as collectors of revenue. One matter at which the Minister might look is the question of standardising what is acceptable in terms of profit where farmers are concerned. Different criteria are used in means testing for general medical service cards, for health contributions, for income tax and for social welfare benefits. There are different rules in all these cases governing what is allowed and what is not allowed. I would ask the Minister to see if some way could be found to standardise what is profit and what is not profit in assessing farmers' incomes.

Capital expenditure has increased from £53 million in 1983 to £55.5 million this year. The Minister did not tell us this morning that last year the Fianna Fáil Government produced the Estimate before they left office. They allocated £55 million for capital development and then this Government on coming into office reduced that figure to £53 million. In effect there is now only £.5 million more than the original Estimate for 1983. There is grave need for a great many projects, and the Minister told us that last year there were over £600 million worth of projects in his Department awaiting sanction. When one considers the spin-off from capital expenditure in terms of building, to say nothing of the spin-off in other manufactures, such as cement, timber, paint and so on, any injection of capital into the building industry is worthy of consideration. Surely, if the Government are sincere in trying to reduce unemployment, they should increase the amount of capital available to the various Government Departments and particularly to the Department of Health. A very small percentage of capital is going to building in the community care area. It is all going to hospitals.

The allocation to the VHI is down from £3 million to £900,000 and that £900,000 applies apparently to previous years. The VHI are getting nothing this particular year. If we look at the Minister's philosophy he wants to charge those who opt for private facilities more and more. Those over £11,000 are not entitled to free comprehensive hospital care and under what the Minister proposes he will create a situation in which there will be a massive increase in the contribution to the VHI to provide adequate cover. Now the VHI should be encouraged to provide more facilities for out-patients and community care. There is a built-in bias towards in-patient facilities in what the VHI provide. They should be encouraged to reverse that policy and provide a range of services for people who stay in the community and receive medical attention as out-patients rather than go into hospital.

The Minister referred to the use of facilities in hospitals by consultants. There is a proposal that consultants should be charged for the use of these facilities in State hospitals. We have had a preview of this in the Minister's opening statement this morning and in the newspapers over the last few days and on the radio last Sunday. The proposal to charge consultants is in my opinion a doctrinaire socialist proposal and nothing else. The Minister knows as well as we know on this side that it is not the consultants who will have to pay but the consumer. He also stated that this was a new arrangement made in 1979. My understanding is that that equipment and those facilities were always available to consultants. There were no specific charges for facilities or equipment.

There are massive cut-backs in health services. You have £24 million out of the health services. The whole idea seems to be that we should introduce this type of socialism and create a situation in which people who want to pay for their own medical care privately and so save the Exchequer should be debarred from doing so. The Minister wants to force these people who may be unable to meet their VHI commitments to use an already over-burdened health service. It will make no difference to the consultants. It will be the patients who will suffer, not the consultants. That will be the effect. If there is a fee for the use of facilities and equipment it is the consumer who will pay. The Minister will not be able to force the consultants to pay. Many consumers, because their incomes are so reduced as a result of this Government's taxation policy, will not be able to join organisations like the VHI and will have to opt for an already over-burdened public health service with a resultant extra charge on the Exchequer. Here, in 1984, in the first two months when there are already cut-backs of £24 million the Minister tells us he will introduce this new charge to force more people into the public health service. It is estimated 175,000 patients will be affected by this decision. These are people who will already have paid their income tax and their health contribution.

An exclusive interview with the Minister in The Irish Press of 29 February carries the headline “Radical Plans for Health”. As far as health services are concerned the only radical party in this House is our party. If one looks at the legislation over the last ten or 15 years one finds the Health Act 1970, the setting up of the health boards, the Medical Practitioners Act 1978, the Abuse of Drugs Act 1979, the Family Planning Act which the Minister's own Government in the seventies were unable to introduce. The Family Planning Act was brought before the House by the leader of our party, Deputy Haughey, and was carried through the Houses of the Oireachtas and put on the Statute Book. In fairness that should gain recognition rather than the throw-away remark that the family planning legislation makes us the laughing-stock of Europe. At least it should be recognised that when the party on this side of the House decided to introduce legislation they were able to come into the Dáil, introduce that legislation and carry it through both Houses of the Oireachtas and put it on the Statute Book, which the Minister's party and the Coalition Government of the day tried to do and were unable to do. We would make more progress if recognition were given to these facts rather than the Government talking about radical plans for health.

I believe that the interview was purely a means of deflecting attention from the day-to-day running of the service. The Minister has responsibility for formulating policy, but he has responsibility also for the day-to-day running of the services. Because the Government are not able to provide the level of care that the people expect, they are thinking up all sorts of new ideas to deflect attention, and a radical solution to the health problems of the nation is one of those ideas. The Minister is quoted as saying that he is absolutely determined that the amount of overtime being worked at hospitals will be reduced. He recognises that there is a need for more efficient outpatient services and a more controlled method of bringing people into hospitals, but there is nothing in his whole Estimate to tell us that he is going to do something to improve the outpatient services, to make them more efficient. There was nothing in his speech this morning about how we are to create a better outpatient service, which we all agree is necessary. People should not be obliged to spend three or four hours in an outpatient department waiting to be dealt with, but people will have to spend longer and longer in out-patient departments as a result of the cutbacks.

The Minister described as interesting the statistics indicating that the consumption of drugs among people under the GMS is three times greater than among the 60 per cent of the people not covered by the scheme. One cannot stress too often that the people covered by the GMS are in the more vulnerable groups in our society. He himself gave the figure this morning that those over 66 years of age while only 10 per cent of the population take up to 40 per cent of the beds. Those in the lower income groups, particularly those with large families, are more susceptible to illness. These are the people included in the GMS.

Another matter I wish to raise is the question of the number of visits to the family doctor by holders of GMS cards. In order to keep the number of visits down doctors may tend to prescribe drugs for a longer period than they would normally do so. If the visitation rate goes up above the national average the doctor must account for it, and I understand that there is a tendency for doctors to prescribe drugs for a month when normally they might do so for only a fortnight in order to avoid bringing the patient back and so putting their visiting rate too high. The working party should look at this aspect of the GMS. If somebody gets a month's supply of tablets and then for one reason or another is chronically ill and has to go into hospital and may not need those tablets, then those tablets are wasted, and we must all be concerned about wastage of drugs.

Regarding the interview yesterday, the Minister said that he is determined that voluntary hospitals which dominate the Dublin scene will be integrated into the health board system. Again this is a bit of doctrinaire socialism and an attempt to deflect attention from the realities of the day-to-day running of the service. I wonder if the Minister has had consultations with the voluntary hospital personnel about this. I believe that the voluntary hospitals are providing an excellent level of service and have made a very valuable contribution to health care in this nation down the years, and that it would be wrong to walk in and take over the voluntary hospitals just because the Department are funding them to over 90 per cent of their needs at present. Has the Minister had consultations with the voluntary hospitals about this? I did not hear any reference to this solution from him this morning.

The Minister spoke about a Green Paper, and in last year's discussion of the Estimate he promised that we would have the Green Paper before the end of 1983. To quote his own words, when speaking on the 1983 Estimate, “before the end of the year”. This is 1 March and there is still no sign of it.

The Minister said that he will be presenting a memorandum on the National Drug Company to the Government over the next month. He went on then to the Family Planning Act. He found insulting to the Irish people — and many members of the Opposition accept this — the provision that requires people to have a prescription for non-medical contraceptives. Generally speaking there are no ideological hang-ups on that except, it is no harm to point out, according to the Minister's statement that makes us the laughing stock of Europe. Many people, including many doctors, believe that it is in the interests of a couple that they should discuss their family planning needs with their family doctor and, having heard about the various methods available, the couple in conjunction with the doctor would decide what is the most appropriate family planning method for them. Many people who accept that as right and who see family planning as part of community health care and not as something isolated, would not consider that it makes us the laughing-stock of Europe that a couple would go to their doctor to discuss various methods of family planning and if they decide on non-medical methods of family planning they would on one occasion only get an authorisation from the doctor that would serve them for their lifetime. The Minister told us in the 1983 Estimate that he had reviewed the legislation. This morning he told us that he has circulated to the Government the findings of his review. If he had that review when the 1983 Estimates were before the House when did he circulate it to the Government? If he circulated it to the Government in June 1983 when he told us he had received it, what has it being doing since 1983, since last June? I wonder if these throw-away remarks of the Minister about the Family Planning Act, 1979 which was introduced and put through this House by a Fianna Fáil Government — a Coalition Government could not do it — are to deflect attention from difficulties within the Government on bringing forward family planning legislation.

Finally, in his interview with The Irish Press, he talked about the Children Bill. Nowhere in all of that interview was there anything radical that I could see to improve the health of the nation, no major contribution to the prevention of illness or to the promotion of health care. The only little bit of radical thinking was the doctrinaire socialism that he will move in and take over the voluntary hospitals, although I know the Minister is not responsible for newspaper headlines.

At a time when everybody is interested in health care, in supporting the promotion of good health and the prevention of illness, it is a matter of some concern to find that the Health Education Bureau are receiving no increase in their allocation this year. They are to receive £1.25 million which is what they received last year and less than what they received from the Fianna Fáil Government in 1982. Therefore, they are receiving one-tenth of 1 per cent of the total health budget. If one examines the total amount allocated for the community protection programme it is £17.65 million out of a total budget of £1,021 million. There would have been something to be said for them having received the odd £21 million, leaving the remaining £1,000 million for the other aspects of the service. Surely the main thrust of any Government's health policy at present must be the prevention of illness and the positive promotion of good health care. The Health Education Bureau maintain that their allocation in 1978 was £1 million——

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: That was for Deputy Haughey's public relations exercise, spending it on horse show prizes.

That was £1 million in 1978, increased by £250,000 by this Government in 1984, which is the same as they received last year. That is a 25 per cent increase during the same period that the Minister told us here this morning the cost of health services went up by 166 per cent. I would ask the Minister where are his and the Government's priorities when the cost of our health services went up 166 per cent, from £400 million to £1,000 million in that period. Yet the Minister could not give any increase since he took up office, except in fact a decrease of £250,000, from an allocation of £1,500,000 from the Fianna Fáil Government in 1982 to £1,250,000 this year. I do not know where the Minister's commitment is.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. Desmond Mr. B. Desmond
Speaker.P: I thought they were happy enough with their budget this year.

I cannot see how they could be happy with it if they want to discharge their responsibility. And they must take note of the World Health Organisation's desire to see, as they say themselves, “health for all” by the year 2000. Surely the Health Education Bureau have a most important role to play in that goal. Surely also there are many projects in which they would like to be involved but in which they cannot because they have not the necessary finance available, for example, programmes for youth, on the problem of alcoholism, and the Minister told us here this morning that there are 45,000 alcoholics in the country. We need a proper programme to alert people to the dangers of alcohol, to the dangers of the misuse of drugs. I was glad to hear the Minister say also this morning that he hoped to introduce legislation on smoking. One would have to question the Government's commitment to an anti-smoking campaign, because always one must ask if there is a conflict of interest between the Minister for Health and the Minister for Finance who receives a lot of revenue from the people who smoke. The health boards have done excellent work in regard to health education. The Eastern Health Board have engaged in some excellent pilot projects, for example, their project on parental skills, on community pride and education for parenthood.

MainHeading.P: Certainly the most serious problem being encountered in this city at present is that of the misuse of drugs. We were told in the House recently that 10 per cent of drug addicts in the 15-24 age group are on heroine, a very dangerous drug. While I listened carefully to the Minister this morning as he told us of the plans he has in mind, apart from giving an allocation to Trinity College to set up a post-graduate course it does not appear that there has been any extra money allocated to the solution of this very serious problem. There was one paragraph of the Minister's remarks here this morning about which I would be most concerned, that dealing with sentences for drug pushers, because the intention is to increase the sentence from 14 years to life. We cannot be sure how long a life sentence will be, it may be seven years, nine years or ten years only. Before introducing that legislation I should prefer that the Minister would increase that maximum sentence for a convicted drug pusher from 14 years to 20 years or 25 years rather than to a life sentence. To amend the law on sentencing to life would be a very serious step indeed. There must be provision to ensure that those who dispense heroine and other serious addictive drugs be punished in a way that will make it entirely unattractive for them to become involved in that sort of activity.

During the year the Minister added new drugs to those on the prescribed occupational diseases list. While this may be more relevant to the Department of Social Welfare I would ask the Minister to examine the situation of, say, somebody who contacts an occupational disease at work and who, because that disease is not on the list of occupational diseases, will not qualify for occupational injury benefit.

The main thrust of the Government's policy should be — and there is no evidence to show that they are supporting this with moneys allocated out of a total of £1,021 million — the promotion of good health and the prevention of illness. It has been said that the greatest single need in medicine in the next 25 years will be to give prevention the degree of scientific and educational attention that has been given to treatment in the past 25 years. Attention was drawn to the prevention of illness in the course of an EEC document, number 82/716 in which it was said and I quote:

Finally, more attention needs to be given to the possible ways and means of reducing the social cost of economic activity (pollution, accidents, etc.) which in the end are paid for by the social protection system in one way or another (sickness, premature disability, accidents at work). This would require a wide range of action over a number of policy fields and demand a major effort of co-ordination within national administrations.

We should like to see a major effort towards the promotion of prevention by our administration. The Health Education Bureau have not got the necessary finance to promote a programme on, say, the correct type of lifestyle for people. The effects of smoking, excessive drinking and an improper diet should be brought to the attention of people. This morning the Minister referred to the problem of hormones and antibiotics in meat and milk. In conjunction with his colleagues in government, the Minister should consider the present situation where the local authority, as sanitary authority, employ veterinary inspectors. This should be a function of the health board rather than the county council concerned. I ask the Minister to ensure that any matter that is a health function be removed from the local authorities and placed where it belongs either with the health boards or with the Department.

We cannot have enough education on matters such as the importance of exercise and the misuse of drugs. I was surprised that the Minister said the Health Education Bureau were satisfied with an allocation that is the same as they received last year, that was £250,000 less than what they received from a Fianna Fáil Government in the previous year and which is only £250,000 higher than what they received in 1978.

I support the Minister fully in what he said this morning regarding immunisation. It is important, following the debate on the use of the whooping cough vaccine, that the public should realise that the risk from whooping cough at the moment is much greater than the risk of brain damage as a result of vaccination. People should not be deterred from having their children immunised.

The Government should also consider the whole matter of the pollution of the environment. It is necessary to ensure that we do not allow anything to happen to our environment that will be detrimental to the interests of the people. The Government have a legitimate role to play in the protection of people from trauma and illness, but we heard nothing about it today. While accidents in the home and industrial accidents may not be the direct responsibility of the Minister for Health, in terms of promoting good health and the prevention of illness they are matters in which he should take an interest. It is important also in terms of health economics. Instead of carrying out research on some of the matters he mentioned this morning, the Minister could usefully research the cost to the health service of maintaining in hospital victims of road accidents and accidents caused to the elderly or to children because homes are not properly protected. If the Minister investigated these matters he would be doing a good service and perhaps he might find some way of reducing costs rather than simply having cutbacks. Fianna Fáil started a scheme allowing special aid for improvements carried out in the homes of the elderly, and this has continued. It has been an excellent scheme. Not alone has it improved the homes of the elderly but I am sure it has contributed to preventing accidents because the homes have been made safer.

In the Minister's speech this morning there was no joy for those who had hoped that the level of health services would be maintained. As the Minister admitted today, there will be a curtailment in the level of the services. He promised a lot of legislation, but he made that same promise last year. He told us then several Bills would be before the House before the end of 1983. This morning he told us some of the Bills will be introduced in the immediate future but others have been put on the long finger.

The Minister dismantled some of our legislation which would have made a valuable contribution to the community last year; I refer to the National Community Development Agency. That agency were not given the opportunities they should have been given. They should have been allowed a chance to show if they were going to make the valuable contribution we believed they would make when the legislation was passed in 1982. Instead, the Minister set up the National Social Service Board and he has promised legislation to combat poverty. However, the National Community Development Agency was sufficient to fulfil their functions and they had the necessary element to research poverty and to do the work the Minister expects the Combat Poverty Agency to do.

The people do not want statistics, reviews or draconian cutbacks. They do not want the type of radical socialism that we heard from the Minister on the radio last Sunday about the consultants and hospital equipment. They do not want the taking over of voluntary hospitals.

In his speech this morning the Minister said nothing about legislation he proposed on private hospitals and private nursing homes. If he hopes to implement such measures he should consult the appropriate people who are involved in private nursing homes. They are very concerned particularly when they hear outbursts of this kind of socialism. It is important that the Minister communicate with them at an early stage and tell them what he has in mind. People expect a proper service without the risks to their health that have been caused as a result of this Government's decision to reduce the level of services by their massive cutbacks.

Speaker.P: The Department of Health are a huge Department and the policies they will pursue in the next 12 months and thereafter are important. The Minister gave us a comprehensive and wide-ranging speech this morning. Non-capital expenditure of £1,064 million is a vast amount of money. It affects the lives of everybody throughout the length and breadth of Ireland in one way or another. Both the Minister and Deputy O'Hanlon referred to some of the points and I will confine myself to a number of details. While the Minister is in the House I am anxious to make a first point which is of interest to my constituency.

MainHeading.P: I refer the Minister to the Tullamore General Hospital and the absolute necessity to have two appointments made there immediately. The hospital requires a permanent obstetrician/gynaecologist and a permanent paediatrician. It has an excellent maternity unit with all the necessary equipment and a back-up of the necessary ancillary services, with a fully qualified nursing staff. It cannot be contradicted that it requires the two permanent appointments I referred to.

I have had the honour to represent the constituency for a number of years and I am asking the Minister to work in harmony with the CEO of the health board to ensure that a situation that occurred there last December and January will never be allowed to recur in that hospital. I will read a letter which appeared in the Tullamore Tribune on 21 January last which will bring home to the House and to the Minister the need to have these appointments made:
Dear Sir,

We wish to lodge a complaint regarding the present procedure whereby Maternity patients are ferried by Ambulance to Portlaoise during each period of time that the Resident Obstetrician/Gynaecologist is on leave and due to the fact that no effort has been made to secure the services of a Locum Obstretician/Gynaecologist for Tullamore Hospital.

We feel that it is not acceptable that maternity patients travel to Tullamore Hospital to have their babies only to be informed that the Obstetrician/Gynaecologist is off duty and that it is necessary for them to travel to Portlaoise General Hospital for delivery.

The least mothers should expect is to feel they are properly cared for at such a special moment. It is vital to be as relaxed as possible at the time of birth. How can a woman relax if she is informed at the last minute that she has to travel twenty-three miles more before she can be given expert medical attention. This news is very depressing and can give patients a most awful shock.

Surely at the best of times this travelling puts the lives of patients and babies at risk but more especially last week-end with dangerous road conditions and gale force winds and with gardaí advising people not to travel. We only have to think of the accident at Durrow for proof of that.

One mother travelled on hazardous roads from Edenderry to Tullamore on Sunday night, in labour. Imagine her distress and shock when upon arrival in Tullamore she was put into an ambulance and transferred to Portlaoise, where she was shortly delivered. Just two hours after the birth of her baby she is ousted out of bed to get ready for the return journey. It is disgraceful that newborn infants of only a few....

The letter is signed by a number of mothers. In his reply, the CEO stated they have been trying to obtain a locum service, but this does not solve a bad situation. It is highly unsatisfactory and downright dangerous because it places the lives of mothers and children at risk. It is not good enough that it should be allowed to continue in 1984.

Therefore, I call on the Minister to have these essential appointments made immediately, and I cannot understand why Deputy Woods, when he was Minister, did not make them. Offaly is a big county stretching from the borders of Tipperary to County Meath. It is such a vast area that the present lack of a proper obstetrician/gynaecologist service cannot be tolerated.

Recently I tabled a question on this subject and the Minister said he intended to advertise for a replacement for the present consultant who has secured appointment in Wexford. The Minister also said that he would advertise for a locum pending the permanent appointment. I am concerned that the first permanent appointment should be made immediately and the second without delay.

There is a paediatric unit in the Tullamore hospital which was provided jointly by the Department and the health board. It is an excellent unit but we have not got a paediatrician to go into it. Consultants have to travel down from Dublin at considerable cost to the Department and the health board. Alternatively, children have to be transferred to Dublin. The vast majority of the staff in the unit at present are living in Dublin. I ask the Minister to remember that rural Ireland has to be looked after as well and must be provided with hospital services, with proper maternity, back-up and ancillary services. I ask the Minister to ensure that these appointments are made and cannot overstate the importance of this to everybody concerned. Regularly mothers and fathers come to me asking for these appointments to be made, because they are unhappy with the position as it is. I put down a question recently about the appointment of a paediatrician. The Minister replied that he was acutely aware of the lack of a proper paediatric service and I was glad to hear that recognition of the problem. He went on to say that in view of the urgency of the situation his Department and the health board were at present considering various proposals for the development of adequate services. It is essential that the Minister provide a paediatrician for Tullamore General Hospital.

Many local district hospitals have a problem in that only one qualified medical practitioner has access to them. In quite a large town with a district hospital, all the doctors in the town or the surrounding area should be allowed the facilities of these hospitals, in conjunction and co-operation with the health board concerned. If such facilities were made available for the medical profession it would benefit many patients, some of whom would not have to be admitted into hospitals for treatment. The Minister should examine this question. I understand this is a matter for the Midland Health Board, but a proper Government policy should be worked out to expand this service.

One important matter referred to by the Minister this morning concerns the very serious drug problem. We are lucky that at present it is, to a large degree, confined to the cities and really large towns. However, those living in the smaller towns in rural Ireland cannot be complacent in this regard. I must place on record how seriously I view the present trend of vigilante groups who are tackling the drug problem. The majority of those forming these protection and vigilante groups are well intentioned and have the welfare of their families and their communities at heart in carrying out these tasks, but the trend is frightening and must be of concern to all Members of this House. It clearly represents a vote of no confidence in our existing institutions — in our courts, in the Garda Síochána and in the Houses of the Oireachtas, which is extremely serious.

The plans for changes in the Misuse of Drugs Act are to be welcomed, but no Act will provide all the answers and all the remedies. One comment by the Opposition spokesman with which I agree opposed the change from an 8 year period of imprisonment to life imprisonment. However it is necessary to increase the number of years from eight to 14 or 20, instead of imposing life imprisonment. That is a wise suggestion to which the Minister and his advisers might listen.

The prevention of crime is what is important, and the prevention of the misuse of drugs is one of the most compelling tasks facing us today. The policies of the Garda Síochána, the courts and both Houses of the Oireachtas must be made more relevant to the problem. The assistance of the Garda Síochána must be made accessible to the people living in housing complexes and huge housing estates and the Ministers for Health and for Justice should have very urgent discussions with Garda policy in view. If necessary, Garda stations or Garda offices of one sort or another will have to be provided in these areas and be manned on a 24 hour basis.

I fully understand the problems faced by gardaí attached to one huge station who on occasion patrol many of these complexes. They have no real feedback or hard information about what is going on. In many instances, it is very sad to state that they are groping in the dark. This is because they are not able to keep in touch and exchange viewpoints with the people living in these areas.

The crime rate has grown in a frightening manner, serious crime particularly, and this must be seriously confronted. The Misuse of Drugs Act is important, and I am glad that the Minister is amending it, working in conjunction with the Garda task force. In conjunction with the Minister for Justice, he will have to examine the role of the Garda in this matter. The direction of policy of the Garda under successive Governments must be closely examined. I should like it to be clearly understood that I am in no way criticising the Garda Síochána but, as is obvious with the growth of the drugs problem, in particular, the policy being pursued must be looked at, to see how it can be adapted and improved.

Many convictions have been obtained by the Garda Síochána with regard to the misuse of drugs, and I congratulate them for their fine and splendid efforts in cracking a large number of the drug rings in Dublin. Statistics for 1982 show that roughly 530,000 district court summonses were issued. Of those, over 480,000 refer to Road Traffic Act offences of one type or another. The amount of Garda man hours spent on this type of duty, on checkpoint duty, traffic duty, on obtaining details of offences, preparing summonses and so on must be examined.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle John J. Ryan
Speaker.P: This has nothing to do with the Department of Health, Deputy. A passing reference would be all right.
I have more or less concluded. I am anxious for co-operation with regard to the drug problem between the Ministers for Health and for Justice.

Speaker.hpid: An Leas-Cheann Comhairle John J. Ryan
Speaker.P: If you stay on the subject of the drug problem, that will be all right.

I hope greater attention will be paid to the tremendous increase in serious crime, and drugs are involved in many of these. I ask for a change in direction of policy in an attempt to combat the present frightening situation. Society has experienced some of the most frighteningly and horrendous crimes immaginable. Confidence must be restored in our Judiciary, our Garda Síochána and the Oireachtas.

MainHeading.P: The vigilantes and the protection groups are very dangerous. A lot of these vigilante groups are gaining some respectability and that is alarming. The two Ministers concerned must put their heads together to remedy this serious problem. That is the reason why I am calling for a change of direction to get to grips with the very serious crimes we have at the moment. I am not underestimating the very important work carried out in relation to the Road Traffic Act.

The drug squad unit should be enlarged and greater training should be provided for this unit. In order to enable the Garda Síochána to enter into areas where there is a serious drug problem, the large housing estates and the different flat complexes, courses should be provided for them in youth training and leadership, sports and all types of community work. If there is a proper planned approach to this we might go a good way towards solving the problems we are facing. There are social problems and age problems to be faced in relation to the Gardaí working in this squad. Those have to be broken down. I hope our gardaí can be given regular training, not just six months in Templemore, but special sessions so that they can be trained in all the areas I have referred to. I am grateful to the Chair for allowing me to speak on these matters which are possibly more for the Department of Justice than the Department of Health.

I would like to say a few words about medical cards. We are told that once a person has an illness which is in the special type illness category that person gets a medical card as of right. Any people who apply for medical cards for children with long-term illness have a lot of problems. Children who suffer from asthma, blind children and deaf children do not get medical cards as of right. Perhaps it is a good thing that no group as of right get medical cards but there is a very serious problem in relation to the children I am talking about. The Minister should look at an extension of the guidelines for the assessment of people who are entitled to medical cards particularly in hardship cases. There should be a much more flexible method of assessment in cases like this.

The Minister referred to the importance of nursing in relation to the whole question of medical care. The Minister should realise the large number of young nurses who are unemployed and the serious problem young girls leaving school are facing because they cannot be trained in Ireland. Many of them have to travel to other countries to qualify as nurses. I know the Minister has not an easy answer to this. I have had discussions with quite a number of married nurses recently. Many of them would be happy to retire from their jobs if there was some attractive package to encourage them to do so. The Minister should encourage married nurses to retire from their jobs by giving them some cash payment on retirement or a number of payments over two or three years. It is very sad to see the number of fully qualified young nurses who are unable to obtain employment. Many of those nurses are forced to leave the country to obtain employment. The Minister and some of his colleagues have already referred to early retirement in many spheres. I encourage the Minister to do something in relation to the early retirement of nurses.

Speaker.P: I am glad of the opportunity to speak in the debate on the very important Estimate for the Department of Health. As a doctor and, more importantly, as an elected member of the South Eastern Health Board I have a particular interest in this area. I am rather apprehensive because, as a consultant, I am aware that the Minister may once again make the claim that some of my colleagues and I may have a vested interest. He made this remark before when we got involved in medical cards for students. I have a vested interest in this discussion in relation to the Health Estimate and I have a vested interest in seeing that our patients receive the best possible health care from any Government.

MainHeading.P: As a consultant in a general hospital I am acutely aware of the serious consequences which the Minister's allocations have had for our health services. This is from a caring Minister for Health, from a Labour Party who demanded the Health portfolio for participation in the Coalition Government. All these cutbacks from a Labour Party who, mark you, brought down the last Fianna Fáil Government in November 1982 on the proposed health cuts are really a case of the poacher turning game keeper. The Minister for Health was probably the most outspoken member of the Labour Party when he opposed the proposed health cuts by Fianna Fáil in 1982. Let us look at the Minister's record and at the 1984 Estimate for Health. There was a shortfall of £26 million in the allocations agreed between the Minister's Department and the various health boards last October. All the health boards have had to make significant cutbacks and this is for the third year running. Surely the Minister must realise that there is a cutoff point beyond which patients will suffer. We cannot continue to cut back and expect the same service.

MainHeading.Title: Ceisteanna—Questions. Oral Answers. - School Milk Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the total number of farmers who are in financial difficulty with the various lending institutions; the number for each county and the number in the case of each lending institution; the number whose difficulties arise as a result of (a) the purchasing of land only and (b) the development of land or the purchase of machinery, etc.; if he has any proposals to alleviate the difficulties for these farmers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

To assist farmers who are in financial difficulty but who can regain viability with the aid of a reduction in interest charges the reduced interest scheme for farmers in severe financial difficulty was introduced in April 1982 by my Department in conjunction with the associated banks and the ACC. The scheme is administered entirely by these lending institutions and my Department are not involved in deciding on the eligibility of individual applicants. It is very important to stress that, because people often come to me saying that the banks told them that my Department decide on eligibility in regard to these schemes. It is the lending institutions who decide this.

After taking account of farmers who applied to more than one of the financial institutions, about 8,200 farmers applied for this relief and some 6,400 have so far been deemed eligible by the lending institutions concerned, in accordance with the terms of the scheme. Of this number, some 4,400 are receiving benefit.
Detailed statistics of the type requested by the Deputy are not available to me.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Obviously about 2,000 farmers were not deemed eligible under this scheme and only 4,400 received benefits. The last time this question was raised I pointed out to the Minister the serious implications for agriculture ——

Speaker.P: A question, please?

Their collateral is very good and there is no reason why restructured loans cannot be provided for 99 per cent of farmers ——

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: The Deputy is making a speech.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: Will the Minister appoint an officer to oversee this scheme?

Since the Deputy raised this question before we have had close co-operation with the lending institutions. Of the 8,200 who applied. 6,400 were approved. It appears that 1,800 farmers did not qualify for inclusion in the scheme for a variety of reasons. Some were not in severe financial difficulties. In the second case the borrowings did not qualify for aid under the scheme. In the third instance, even with the aid of the scheme they could not become viable. Other reasons included net assets being in excess of £200,000 or land purchase being in excess of 120 acrea. Because the farmer must furnish his reconstruction plan before he can be granted the interest relief, only about 4,400 applicants out of the 6,400 applicants are so far receiving benefit. The remaining 2,000 include those who have not yet submitted plans to the lending institutions, those who have not yet accepted the offers sent to them and those who are still in negotiation with the lending institutions on their applications. People who might have been successful have not followed up their applications.

There are an infinite number of reasons for people being in serious financial difficulty and it would cost a tremendous amount of money to solve that problem. Speaker.P: The Minister was asked to widen the scope and to consider independent banks outside the national banking system. Has anything been done in that regard?
I was advised that it could not be extended to any other lending institutions, that these were the only ones which were volunteering.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick

I agree that some appalling advice has been given in the past and many of the people who gave this appalling advice are not now being very forthcoming when it comes to making a settlement.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will ensure that the maximum quantity of home grown wheat is utilised for flour milling.

It has always been my view that home grown wheat should be used to the greatest extent possible in the manufacture of flour in this country and I have lost no opportunity to make this view known. However, the arrangements for the growing of the wheat and its utilisation are essentially matters between wheat growers and flour millers.

Is the Minister aware that in 1978 2 per cent of our flour needs were imported and that this had grown by 1983 to 22 per cent? Is he aware that certain firms closed their mills here and continued operating in Britain and elsewhere in the knowledge that they could import flour here? Does the Minister not consider this to be very detrimental to our balance of payments and to our self-sufficiency in an emergency? Surely there is some action open to him.

Of course we are concerned about the level of flour imports. In order to prevent them one would have to be able to prove to the EEC Commission that these imports constituted dumping. My advice is that such a case cannot be made on the basis of present imports.

We have approximately 180,000 acres of winter wheat this year, a great percentage of which could be milled. Does the Minister not agree that some move must be made to see that winter and spring wheat as far as possible is milled into flour rather than converted into animal feed while we import our flour needs?
The French would block the ports.

The problem is market trends. The cost of feedingstuffs is leading people to put more wheat into provender mills rather than into bread making and flour mills. I do not think there is much we can do about it.

asked the Minister for Agriculture if he will agree that the pictures taken at a coursing meeting in Clonmel and recently published in the media (details supplied) clearly illustrate the barbaric and cruel nature of hare coursing; and whether he will consider requesting the Joint Committee on Legislation to review the existing law which permits live hare coursing and request them to seek public submissions to ascertain the level of public support for the enactment of legislation to ban hare coursing and to empower them to prepare the necessary draft legislation if the submissions received by the committee confirm that there is overwhelming public support for the enactment of such legislation.

I take representations from all sides into consideration. That goes without saying.
Does the Minister accept that the continued sucess of the greyhound industry is not dependent on the continued existence of hare coursing?
I am not convinced that that is the case. It is one of the many matters we will have to look at closely.

Speaker.hpid: An Ceann Comhairle Thomas J. (Cavan) Fitzpatrick
Speaker.P: I think we have coursed this hare long enough.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West): In view of the uncertainty being created by people who are against hare coursing, could the Minister indicate when he is likely to receive the report from Bord na gCon and when he is likely to make a decision?

asked the Minister for Agriculture the number of farmers in County Cavan who had spent money on farm modernisation prior to 9 February 1983 under the guidance of his officials, who were refused participation and who are eligible to benefit from the new scheme.

I appreciate the final sentence in the Minister's reply. Will the Minister accept any responsibility in view of the fact that his officials at local level were advising on the schemes that were disrupted by the Minister for Finance, Deputy Dukes, in his budget speech on 9 February 1983? Will the Minister agree that there must be some legal responsibility in his Department for work carried out under the advice of officials of his Department?
